> * joint angles
> * forces on body parts
>
> Those are the things that an actual human being is
> able to sense directly.

I've been thinking about this idea quite a bit- things
we can sense directly and "senses" we deduce from our
more direct senses.  Can we directly sense joint
angles?  I'm guessing not.  I think we probably deduce
that from our more direct "force" senses (i.e. sense
of touch).  ...Not that that matters for this project.
 Of course, using simulated senses we ("real") humans
don't have can help a simulated human.  However, I
like the idea of making simulated humans mimic real
humans as closely as possible since real humans seem
to work pretty well.

I think there's a term for the sense of "knowing your
limbs' positions, orientations, etc." is the
"proprioceptive system."  So maybe an artificial
neural network could build this sort of mental model
given some primitive input.

Another sense could be the vestibular system (the
circular tubes in our ears that help us sense angular
velocities).  That would be pretty simple to implement
and seems like it would help.

Another big thing on my to-do list is a sense of
sight.  The two main options I've thought of are
these:

1.  Ray-casting.  Shoot a grid of rays out from the
face that each return the distance of the nearest
intersection (i.e. distance sensors).  More rays could
be added throughout evolution.  I've heard that such
intersection testing in large quantities is pretty
expensive if the environment is complex.

2.  Use some sort of image processing/computer vision.

Tyler
